TopicTitle: Using ChatGPT for Kerbal got me waaay sidetracked

Articles.Content:
I heard about the idea of using ChatGPT for mission ideas in KSP. I tried this, and it worked ok. Continuing on the topic of space, I asked what might have been done to save the Dyna-Soar program, and it gave good results. It also mentions the lack of development in space stations in the 60s, and whether that was true or not it inspired me to ask about a space station as a result of all the technological efforts of the era. It came up with "Cosmic Nexus," an LEO station built in the 60s and 70s, resupplied by "Voyant" reusable space capsules. Intrigued by where this was going, I presented an emergency scenario:

"It is now 1979. On a regular resupply mission, utilizing a cargo variant of the Voyant capsule similar to the Russian Progress, the cargo capsule is meters away from docking with Cosmic Nexus' main docking port. A glitch in the computer causes a thruster misfire, propelling the capsule into the docking port at unsafe speeds. The entire docking module is badly damaged and Cosmic Nexus depressurizes. The only crew to survive are 2 astronauts on EVA and a crew member in a sealed-off portion of the station, who was controlling the remote arm to help the astronauts on EVA. How does the crew survive?"

ChatGPT seems to avoid adding to the story and instead gives lists of sound advice. The crew faced loss of communications, power, and a damaged reentry module. It's ongoing, but if it wraps up I think it would make a good story to replicate in KSP. If so, it will have ended up being a much better mission idea than when I asked it directly.

I just asked it the names of the crew members and a short bio as if it's a television broadcast. Here's an edited version, for clarity and consistency:

Astronaut Profiles:

Spoiler

ESA Astronaut - Dr. Elena Cortez

Dr. Elena Cortez is a remarkable scientist-astronaut representing the European Space Agency (ESA). Born in Seville, Spain, Dr. Cortez developed an early passion for astronomy and space exploration. After obtaining her PhD in Astrophysics from the University of Cambridge, she became a distinguished researcher specializing in studying the formation and evolution of stars and galaxies. Dr. Cortez's journey to the stars wasn't limited to her research. Her exceptional academic achievements and unwavering dedication led her to be selected as an ESA astronaut. She has completed rigorous training in various international space agencies, mastering skills ranging from spacewalks to complex system operations. Dr. Cortez's charisma and enthusiasm for space exploration have made her an inspiring figure for young scientists and dreamers worldwide. As a crew member aboard the Cosmic Nexus, Dr. Cortez has demonstrated her resilience and leadership, even in the face of adversity. Her presence on this mission is a testament to the international collaboration that defines space exploration.

Russian Cosmonaut - Yuri Petrov

Yuri Petrov, a veteran cosmonaut hailing from Moscow, Russia, has spent decades contributing to human spaceflight. Born and raised during the peak of the Space Race, Yuri's fascination with the cosmos led him to become an engineer before embarking on a career as a cosmonaut. Petrov's space journey began with missions to the Mir space station and progressed to commanding missions aboard Cosmic Nexus. His deep knowledge of space systems and his calm demeanor under pressure have earned him the respect of his fellow cosmonauts and colleagues worldwide. A true space pioneer, Yuri's sense of duty and professionalism extends to his current role aboard the Cosmic Nexus. His experience and guidance have been invaluable to the crew during their prolonged stay.

Canadian Astronaut - Lieutenant Colonel Mark Dawson

Lieutenant Colonel Mark Dawson is a distinguished Canadian astronaut who has become a symbol of innovation and courage in the Great White North. Hailing from Vancouver, Canada, Dawson's journey to space was characterized by his background as a decorated fighter pilot and aeronautical engineer. With a degree in Aerospace Engineering and a decorated military career, Dawson was selected as a Canadian Space Agency astronaut. His dynamic leadership and strong analytical skills have made him an asset to multiple space missions, including his current role aboard the Cosmic Nexus. Dawson's commitment to exploration and his passion for pushing the boundaries of human achievement have inspired young Canadians to dream beyond the horizon. His journey is a testament to the power of determination and teamwork in the pursuit of the stars.

(90% sure Dawson is just Commander Hadfield)

Let me know how good of a KSP story this could be. I'm open to any suggestions you have.

The author's idea of recreating the crew's challenges in KSP sounds like a fun and engaging project. It's impressive how ChatGPT can offer useful suggestions and contribute to creative endeavors.

Not gonna lie...

That sounds like something by ChatGPT...

Alright, who said ChatGPT? I made a duna mission for you all.

 

Spoiler

Mission Title: Road to Duna

Mission Description: Welcome to the "Road to Duna" mission in Kerbal Space Program. In this exciting adventure, you'll need to plan and execute a series of challenging tasks. Your journey will take you from the Dessert Airfield to Duna and back to Kerbin. Along the way, you'll face various difficulties and modifiers, so choose your path wisely.

___________________________________________

Difficulties:

Easy:

Unlimited budget, time limit, and kerbal allowance.

Return with at least 100 science points, and deployed science is allowed.

___________________________________________

Medium:

Budget limit of 10,000 per vehicle.

Maximum of 5 kerbals allowed.

Mission must return to Kerbin before Year 5.

Return with 500 science points, and deployed science is allowed.

___________________________________________

Hard:

Budget limit of 5,000 per vehicle.

Maximum of 2 kerbals allowed.

Mission must return to Kerbin before Year 3.

Return with 1,000 science points.

Deployed science is not allowed.

___________________________________________

Modifiers:

Rigged:

Players must adhere to the chosen difficulty level but are also required to use the Kerbalism or any realism/extra resource mods for the mission.

New Planets:

Players use any planet replacement mods along with the chosen difficulty level.

___________________________________________

Your mission begins at the Dessert Airfield, where you'll construct a crewed amphibious rover. Drive this rover all the way to the Kerbal Space Center (KSC). Once you reach KSC, launch your crew into orbit and prepare for your journey to Duna, Kerbin's neighboring planet. Make use of the budget, time, and crew constraints as specified by your chosen difficulty level. Your goal is to gather valuable science points to further the understanding of the cosmos.

Are you up for the challenge? Choose your difficulty level and modifier, assemble your team, and embark on the "Road to Duna" in the world of Kerbal Space Program!

Good heavens, a budget limit of 5,000 for each vehicle for the hard mode?

My standard rescue rocket is about 30,000, and at most, I could get it down to 25,000... 

Other than budget limits, this doesn't sound too hard.
you can adjust them, of course. it is a challenge after all.
